   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. currently gas exchanging well on current vent settings.
   recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and
   inability to clear secretions.
   - blood, sputum cultures
   - empiric VAP therapy for now if no cultures + at 48 hours will
   discontinue (vanc/zosyn/cipro)
   - chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - wean FIO2 by O2sats
   # Altered Mental Status: Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic
   encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level),
   hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status)
   though this was not captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in
   [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  Had
   extensive neuro work up at that time which was largely unrevealing
   including LP, paraneoplastic labs which were negative, SPEP/UPEP,
   MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical illness myopathy.  Patient
   does not appear to be in nonconvulsive status as she does react to
   noxious stimuli and appears to calm when addressed
   - Neuro consult in AM
   - Continue dilatin at prior dosing
   - Could pursue LP although MS appears similar to that in [**Month (only) 1563**] based on
   OMR, and LP at that time was unrevealing
   # Vomiting: Unable to assess pain currently given altered mental
   status. Abdominal exam most notable for distension and firm stool
   filled colon in LLQ. KUB showing air throughout colon without evidence
   obstruction.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Trending down overnight.
   - Repeat EKG this AM
   - Complete r/o MI this morning
   - Continue aspirin
   - Once rules out can d/c plavix
   # Acute renal failure: Likely from pre-renal etiology in the setting of
   poor intake.  Patient appears dry on exam.  Chronically with foley so
   unlikely obstruction.
   - Will trend Cr
   - IVF
   - Renally dose meds
    # Anemia: Currently elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Currently normotensive although in the setting of
   dehydration and potoential infection.
   - Hold anti-hypertensives for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: On TF at nursing home. Currently NPO.
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:23 AM
   22 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:24 AM

   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: FULL
   Disposition: ICU
Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old individual with a history of seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence, hypoxia, and altered mental status. The patient was intubated and placed on invasive ventilation due to respiratory failure. The recent exacerbation of respiratory failure is likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and inability to clear secretions.

The patient's altered mental status is unclear, possibly due to generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated Dilantin level), hypoxia, or underlying seizure disorder. The patient does not appear to be in nonconvulsive status as they react to noxious stimuli and seem to calm when addressed.

The patient has also been experiencing vomiting, with an inability to assess pain due to altered mental status. The abdominal exam shows distension and a firm stool-filled colon in the lower left quadrant. There is no evidence of obstruction on the KUB (kidneys, ureters, and bladder) x-ray.

The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes are unlikely to represent acute ischemia given the unchanged EKG from prior. They are trending down overnight. A repeat EKG this morning will be done, and a complete ruling out of myocardial infarction (MI) will be performed. The patient will continue taking aspirin, and Plavix can be discontinued once MI is ruled out.

The patient likely has acute renal failure from pre-renal etiology in the setting of poor intake. They appear

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, transferred for hypoxia, and altered mental status. They are currently on invasive ventilation due to respiratory failure of unclear etiology. Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and inability to clear secretions. 

The patient has altered mental status, which is unclear if it is generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated Dilantin level), hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder. Neuro consult is requested in the morning. 

The patient also has vomiting, unable to assess pain currently given altered mental status. Abdominal exam shows distension and firm stool-filled colon in LLQ. KUB showing air throughout colon without evidence of obstruction. Aggressive bowel regimen is recommended. 

Elevated cardiac enzymes are unlikely to represent acute ischemia given unchanged EKG from prior. Trending down overnight. Repeat EKG this AM, complete r/o MI this morning, continue aspirin, and once rules out, can discontinue Plavix. 

Acute renal failure is likely from pre-renal etiology in the setting of poor intake. The patient appears dry on exam. Chronically with Foley so unlikely obstruction. Will trend Cr, IVF, and renally dose meds. 

Anemia is currently elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting dehydration/volume contraction. Trend Hct, IVF prn. 

Hypertension

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Currently gas exchanging well on home vent settings.
   Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and
   inability to clear secretions.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Empiric VAP therapy for now, if no growth, will dc antibiotics
   (vanc/zosyn) in am tomorrow.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats
   # Altered Mental Status: Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic
   encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level),
   hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status)
   though this was not captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in
   [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At
   that time, appears to have had similar mental/functional status that
   she has now; however, per notes and her son, had been making
   improvements since that time.  During her last admission, had extensive
   neuro work up at that time which was largely unrevealing including LP,
   paraneoplastic labs which were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG
   concerning for critical illness myopathy.  Patient does not appear to
   be in nonconvulsive status as she does react to noxious stimuli and
   appears to calm when addressed.
   - Neuro consult this AM
   - Continue dilatin at prior dosing
   # Vomiting: Unable to assess pain currently given altered mental
   status. Abdominal exam most notable for distension and firm stool
   filled colon in LLQ. KUB showing air throughout colon without evidence
   obstruction.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trending down overnight.
   - Repeat EKG this AM
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to admission
   at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Likely from pre-renal etiology in the setting of
   poor intake.  Patient appears dry on exam.  Chronically with foley so
   unlikely obstruction.
   - Will trend Cr
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue IVF for now.
   Continue to monitor volume status.
   - Renally dose meds
    # Anemia: Currently elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Currently normotensive although in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection.
   - Hold anti-hypertensives for now
   ICU Care

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 76-year-old individual with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, hypoxia, and altered mental status. The patient was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and altered mental status.

The patient's medical history includes chronic vent dependence, seizure disorder, and poor dentition. They have been on multiple medications including Piperacillin, Vancomycin, Zosyn, Levetiracetam, Lorazepam, Ondansetron, Acetaminophen, and others.

On examination, the patient has a tracheostomy in place, dry mucous membranes, and a sacral pressure ulcer. They also have increased muscle tone with cogwheeling/rigidity, right CN VII palsy, and a tongue deviated to the left.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, normal platelet count, elevated creatinine levels, and abnormal electrolyte levels including low potassium and magnesium.

The patient has had several cultures drawn, all of which have shown no growth. An EEG showed encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.

The assessment and plan include the following:
- Respiratory Failure: The patient has underlying respiratory failure of unclear etiology. They are currently gas exchanging well on home vent settings but recently experienced an exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and inability to clear secretions.
- Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status

The patient is on empiric VAP therapy and will have their antibiotics discontinued if no growth is observed. Chest physiotherapy and weaning of FiO2 are planned. The patient's altered mental status is likely due to generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs, hypoxia, or underlying seizure disorder. Neuro consult is recommended. Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with chronic respiratory failure who was admitted with concerns of seizure onset. The EEG showed no active seizure activity, and neurology input for medication changes has been implemented. The patient has persistent ventilatory failure with intermittent tracheal mask trials. There is a plan to try pressure support ventilation weaning today and trial a brief tracheal mask trial if respiratory system compliance is favorable. Antibiotics will be discontinued as there is no evidence of significant infection, and it is likely that the patient has aspiration pneumonitis. The patient will continue on Keppra for seizure disorder and Dilantin dosing will also be continued. Hypertension is a chronic issue and medications will be restarted given hemodynamic stability. In the ICU, the patient will receive nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient's code status remains full code, and the patient will remain in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has persistent ventilatory failure, which can lead to further respiratory compromise if not managed appropriately.
2. Aspiration Pneumonitis: The patient may be at risk for developing aspiration pneumonia due to intermittent tracheal mask trials and chronic respiratory failure.
3. Seizure Disorder: Although the EEG showed no active seizure activity, there is a history of reported seizure activity prior to admission. The patient may require

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: Underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by
   aspiration and inability to clear secretions.  Per son pt was
   tolerating hours of [**Name (NI) **] at NH. Currently gas exchanging well on home
   vent settings. Has been tolerating PSV/CPAP since yesterday at 1:00pm.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures drawn, no growth on urine or blood,
   sputum with 1+ GPRs,  unlikely to be pathogen
   - Will d/c VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,
   fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS trial today ([**11-22**]), RSBI this am
   110.
   - Can attempt short trial of trach mask today if patient can tolerate.
   # Altered Mental Status: Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic
   encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level),
   hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status)
   though this was not captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in
   [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At
   that time, appears to have had similar mental/functional status that
   she has now; however, per notes and her son, had been making
   improvements since that time.  During her last admission, had extensive
   neuro work up at that time which was largely unrevealing including LP,
   paraneoplastic labs which were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG
   concerning for critical illness myopathy.  Patient does not appear to
   be in nonconvulsive status as she does react to noxious stimuli and
   appears to calm when addressed.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, pt may have missed a
   dose, will check a level on Monday
   - Started Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   # Vomiting: Had KUB yesterday which showed stool in [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have
   been worsening residuals, vomiting and risk for aspiration. S/p
   aggressive bowel regimen with passage of large BM.
   -Continue to hold TF for now.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trending down overnight.
   - Repeat EKG with no change
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC'd plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to
   admission at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Resolved. Likely from pre-renal etiology in the
   setting of poor intake.  Patient initally appeared quite dry on exam.
   Chronically with foley so unlikely obstruction.
   - Trending Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.1 with
   hydration
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue IVF for now.
   Continue to monitor volume status.
   - Renally dose meds
   # Anemia: Still elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on home
   meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, will restart home lopressor given
   persistent HTN.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Still NPO for now given regurgitation, consider trial of trophic feeds
   today
   Glycemic Control:  Adequate

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 76-year-old with a history of seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence, transferred for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
- The patient has respiratory failure of unclear etiology, recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and inability to clear secretions.
- Blood, urine, sputum cultures were drawn, with no growth on urine or blood, sputum with 1+ GPRs, unlikely to be pathogen.
- VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn will be discontinued given lack of culture data, fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA.
- Chest PT and aggressive pulmonary toilet are recommended.
- The patient's altered mental status is unclear if generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level), hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder.
- Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, pt may have missed a dose, will check a level on Monday.
- Started Keppra.
- EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
- The patient had KUB yesterday which showed stool in the colon, and they have been worsening residuals, vomiting, and risk for aspiration.
- Aggressive bowel regimen with passage of large BM is ongoing.
- Continue to hold TF for now.
- The patient has elevated cardiac enzymes, but it is unlikely to represent acute ischemia given unchanged EKG from prior.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old individual with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and transfer for hypoxia and altered mental status. The patient is currently on CPAP/PSV ventilation mode and has shown improvement in gas exchange. The patient has been tolerating spontaneous breathing trials and is expected to continue with weaning of FiO2 and PS trial today. There are concerns regarding respiratory failure, altered mental status, vomiting, elevated cardiac enzymes, acute renal failure, anemia, and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure may worsen if they are unable to clear secretions and maintain adequate gas exchange.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status could be due to generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs, hypoxia, or underlying seizure disorder. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and appropriate treatment.
3. Vomiting: The patient's worsening residuals and risk for aspiration need to be closely monitored. Aggressive bowel regimen and passage of large BM have been initiated.
4. Elevated Cardiac Enzymes: Although unlikely to represent acute ischemia, the elevated troponins may be due to hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions. Close monitoring is required.
5. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure has resolved, likely from a pre-renal etiology. Continued monitoring of Cr and BUN

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence. They were transferred for hypoxia and altered mental status. The patient has been on various medications including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and seizure medications. They have also undergone multiple interventions such as tracheostomy, ventilation settings adjustment, and chest physiotherapy. The patient's condition has shown improvement in terms of gas exchange and mental status. However, they still require ongoing medical management for several issues.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure of unclear etiology may worsen if they are unable to clear secretions or if there is further deterioration in lung function.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has shown growth of oral flora in the sputum culture, indicating a possible infection. This could lead to VAP if not appropriately managed.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status may continue to fluctuate due to various factors such as infection, medications, hypoxia, or underlying seizure disorder.
4. Vomiting/Regurgitation: The patient has a history of vomiting and regurgitation, which can lead to aspiration and worsening respiratory status.
5. Elevated Cardiac Enzymes: Although the elevated troponin levels may not represent acute ischemia, monitoring for any signs of cardiac dysfunction is essential.
6. Acute Renal Failure: The patient

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: Underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by
   aspiration and inability to clear secretions.  Per son pt was
   tolerating hours of [**Name (NI) **] at NH. Currently gas exchanging well on home
   vent settings. Has been tolerating PSV/CPAP since yesterday at 1:00pm.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures drawn, no growth on urine or blood,
   sputum with 1+ GPRs/GNR,  will continue to follow micro
   - D/c
d VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,
   fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA, growing what
   appears to be oral flora in sputum culture.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS trial today ([**11-22**]), did not tolerate
   [**4-22**], RSBI this am 110.
   - Can attempt short trial of trach mask today if patient can tolerate.
   # Altered Mental Status: Siginificantly improved since admission.
   Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection,
   drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level), hypoxia, or from underlying
   seizure disorder (non-convulsive status) though this was not captured
   on EEG monitoring during last admission in [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU
   (showed only encephalopathic background).  At that time, appears to
   have had similar mental/functional status that she has now; however,
   per notes and her son, had been making improvements since that time.
   During her last admission, had extensive neuro work up at that time
   which was largely unrevealing including LP, paraneoplastic labs which
   were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical
   illness myopathy.  Patient is currently interactive and follows
   commands.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, will check a level on
   Monday
   - Started Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   # Vomiting/regurgitation: Had KUB on admission showing stool in the
   [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have led to worsening residuals, vomiting and aspiration.
   S/p aggressive bowel regimen with BM at this time.  Regurgitation also
   improved at this time.
   - Will restart TF this morning and increase as tolerated to goal,
   continue to check for residuals.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trended down since admission.
   - Repeat EKG with no change
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC'd plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to
   admission at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Resolved. Likely from pre-renal etiology in the
   setting of poor intake.  Patient initally appeared quite dry on exam.
   Chronically with foley so unlikely obstruction.
   - Trending Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.1 with
   hydration
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue IVF for now.
   Continue to monitor volume status.
   - Renally dose meds
   # Anemia: Still elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on home
   meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, will uptitrate clonidine today given
   persistent hypertension.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Still NPO for now given regurgitation, consider trial of trophic feeds
   today
   Glycemic Control:  Adequate
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:21 AM
   22 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:24 AM

   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care

   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU, screening for LTAC
Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 76-year-old with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and transfered for hypoxia and altered mental status.
- The patient has been tolerating pressure support ventilation/clearing the airway pressure (PSV/CPAP) since yesterday at 1:00 pm.
- Blood, urine, and sputum cultures have been drawn, with no growth on urine or blood, and sputum showing 1+ Gram-positive rods/gram-negative rods (GNR).
- The patient's mental status has significantly improved since admission.
- The patient had an extensive neuro workup during the last admission, which was largely unrevealing.
- The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes are unlikely to represent acute ischemia given the unchanged EKG from prior.
- The patient's acute renal failure has resolved, likely from a pre-renal etiology in the setting of poor intake.
- The patient's anemia is still elevated above prior baseline, suggesting dehydration/volume contraction.
- The patient's hypertension has improved with restart of home medications.
- The patient is NPO for now due to regurgitation, and a trial of trophic feeds may be considered today.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure of unclear etiology may worsen, leading to further difficulty in gas exchange and ventilation.
2. Ventilator-associated Pneumonia (VAP): The

   Assessment and Plan
   76 yo female with history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator
   dependence who now has admission for hypoxemia and altered mental
   status and aspiration pneumonitis. At this time with reasonable minimal
   change in overall therapy have been able to move to successful trial of
   PSV.  This may well represent an improvement in ventilator
   requirement.  This is likelly attributable to improved pneumonitis and
   patient pulmonary compliance.
   1)Respiratory Failure-
   Does have baseline ventilator dependence which may be related to chest
   wall restriction and need for ventilator support.  Given improvement
   here would work towards wean of support.  What may be required is to
   have patient out of bed and upright to allow mechanical advantage to
   facilitate ventilation.
   -PSV to [**9-22**] today
change supported by good success in PSV mode of
   support at this time
   -Will continue to follow culture results in setting of antibiotics
   discontinued.
   -OOB when possible
   -RSBI-110
   -Will trial return to A/C support at night if worsening hypercarbia
   seen
   2)Seizure-
   -Continue Keppra
   -Continue Dilantin
   -Exam much improved
   -Appreciate neuro support
   2.5)Acute Renal Failure-
   -Improving with adequate fluid support and patient moving to baseline
   clearance by Creatining
   2.8)Hypertension-
   Patient with improved control with return to labetolol.  Will move to
   patient home dosing and return clonidine as next [**Doctor Last Name **] from home
   dosing.  Will tolerate modest elevations in the setting of ventilator
   weaning.
   3)ICU-Paitent with good stability and reasonable to consider transfer
   to facility for chronic ventilatory unit
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Patient with Bm and will look to advance diet via enteral
   route today
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence, admitted for hypoxemia and altered mental status. She has aspiration pneumonitis and is currently on a trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV). The patient's baseline ventilator dependence may be related to chest wall restriction, and the goal is to wean support. She will continue to follow culture results while antibiotics are discontinued, and will be out of bed when possible. The respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV mode, set Vt of 450 mL, PS of 12 cmH2O, RR set at 14, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, and RSBI of 155. 

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 171/80 to 177/86 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The physical examination reveals a tracheostomy in place, dullness on percussion, diminished breath sounds, and the patient is unable to stand. 

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.5 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, platelet count of 272 K/uL, creatinine level of 1.3 mg/dL, troponin-T level of 0

   - D/c
d VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,

   appears to be oral flora in sputum culture.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS trial today, follow RISBI.
   - Can attempt short trial of trach mask today if patient can tolerate.
   # Altered Mental Status: Siginificantly improved since admission and at
   baseline.   Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from
   infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level), hypoxia, or from
   underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status) though this was not
   captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro
   ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At that time, appears to
   have had similar mental/functional status that she has now; however,
   per notes and her son, had been making improvements since that time.

   which was largely unrevealing including LP, paraneoplastic labs which
   were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical
   illness myopathy.  Patient is currently interactive and follows
   commands.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, -> level subtherapeutic
   this AM, d/w neuro and will give 1x loading dose today.
   - Started Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence. She was admitted for hypoxia and altered mental status. The patient has several medical complications and conditions that need to be addressed.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure of unclear etiology. Recent exacerbation is likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and inability to clear secretions. She is tolerating pressure support ventilation (PSV)/continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) well and has been gas exchanging well on home vent settings. It is planned to attempt a trial of tracheostomy mask.

2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has significantly improved since admission and at baseline. It is unclear if the altered mental status is due to generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level), hypoxia, or underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status). Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin with a loading dose today.

3. Vomiting/regurgitation: The patient had stool in the stomach on admission, which may have contributed to worsening residuals, vomiting, and aspiration. An aggressive bowel regimen has been started, including bowel movements at this time. Regurgitation also improved at this time. Reglan will be started standing to assist with bowel movements and avoid further aspiration.

4. Elevated cardiac enzymes: The patient's elevated troponins are unlikely to represent acute ischemia

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence. She was admitted for increased hypoxemia and altered mental status, both of which have improved. The most likely cause of her acute decompensation is aspiration pneumonitis, which has improved with low-grade pressure support ventilation (PSV) requirement. The patient still depends on a ventilator, which may be related to chest wall restriction. The plan is to try a spontaneous breathing trial today and if unsuccessful, obtain further mechanics. The patient is expected to do best when out of bed and upright.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may recur if she does not successfully wean off the ventilator or if there is a recurrence of aspiration pneumonitis.
2. Seizure: The patient has a history of seizure disorder, and there is a need for ongoing seizure management while in the ICU.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient has improving acute renal failure, and it is important to monitor renal function and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Hypertension: The patient still has substantially high blood pressure, and additional antihypertensive therapy may be required.
5. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to her prolonged ventilator dependence. Measures such as elevating the head of bed and proper hygiene practices should be implemented to prevent VAP.

Renal function tests show normal creatinine levels, while liver function tests are within normal limits. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 27-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of respiratory distress. Upon admission, the patient's vital signs were unstable, with high blood pressure and tachycardia. He required immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation. The patient has a history of asthma and is allergic to shellfish. His last dose of antibiotics was administered on [**2115-4-16**] at 03:15 PM. The patient is receiving heparin sodium as prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He is also on other ICU medications, including Heparin Sodium, Nutrition (Nutren Pulmonary), and Glycemic Control.

Review of Systems:
The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the addition of mild abdominal pain.

Physical Examination:
The patient's peripheral vascular examination reveals weak and thready pulses bilaterally. His skin is pale and diaphoretic. Neurologic examination shows decreased verbal response to commands and decreased movement. The patient's tone is normal.

Lab Results:
The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 13.5, anemia with a Hct level of 30.1, and thrombocytosis with a Plt count of 272. Other notable lab values include elevated Troponin-T levels at 0.39, TCO2 at 28, and Glucose at 101. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range.

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the provided information, potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period, increasing the risk of developing VAP.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient is receiving heparin sodium as prophylaxis against DVT, indicating an increased risk for blood clots. If a clot were to form and dislodge, it could lead to a potentially life-threatening PE.
3. Stress ulcer: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and the use of corticosteroids for asthma management increase the risk of stress ulcer development.
4. Nosocomial infections: The patient's immunocompromised state due to mechanical ventilation and medications increases the risk of nosocomial infections.
5. Barotrauma: The patient's high plateau pressure and PIP values indicate the possibility of barotrauma, which is lung injury caused by excessive airway pressures during mechanical ventilation.

Please note that this is a summary of the provided information, and further assessment and evaluation by a healthcare professional are necessary for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

She was admitted for increased hypoxemia and altered mental status. The patient suffered from a PEA arrest due to hypoxemia/mucous plugging but has since improved.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has chronic respiratory failure with unclear etiology (NM vs. chest wall restriction). Aspiration pneumonitis appears to be the most likely cause of her acute decompensation. Complications such as pneumonia or further episodes of respiratory failure could occur if the underlying cause is not properly managed.

2. Altered mental status: The patient experienced altered mental status post-PEA arrest. Possible causes include post-cardiac arrest syndrome or other factors such as infection or medication side effects. Monitoring for any further decline in mental status and addressing potential underlying causes is crucial.

3. Seizure disorder: The patient has a history of seizure disorder, and it is important to continue current anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) with neurology's help. Any signs of seizure recurrence should be promptly managed.

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of chronic respiratory failure, on mechanical ventilation, and recent neurological decline admitted following aspiration pneumonia and possible seizure with hypoxemia and altered mental status. The patient suffered a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest due to hypoxemia/mucous plugging on day PTA.

The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 153/82 mmHg to 120/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)/pressure support ventilation (PSV) with a set tidal volume (Vt) of 450 mL, respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 111, plateau pressure (Plateau) of 22 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 50%.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, clear breath sounds bilaterally, symmetric chest expansion, and soft non-tender abdomen with present bowel sounds. Neurological examination shows attentiveness, ability to follow simple commands, and response to stimuli but movement, tone, and deep tendon reflexes are not assessed.

Laboratory results indicate a white blood cell count (WBC) of 13.5 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hct) of 30.1%, platelet count (Plt) of 272 K/uL, blood glucose of 101 mg/dL, creatinine (Cr) of 1.3 mg/dL, troponin-T of 0.39 ng/mL, and C-reactive protein (CRP) of 28 mg/dL. Other lab values including electrolytes and cardiac enzymes are within normal range.

Microbiology results show rare gram-negative rods (>25 pmn, <10 epi) in the sputum sample collected on day 4-12.

Assessment and plan:
1. Altered mental status - possibly post-PEA arrest. Head CT is normal, EEG shows no evidence of seizure, and no obvious infection is present. The neuro team believes the mental status is at baseline.
2. sz d/o - continue current anti-epileptic medications.
3. Weakness - possibly critical illness myopathy. Sural/gastrocnemius nerve biopsy is planned for 4/19.
4. Resp failure - chronic respiratory failure unclear, possibly neurogenic or chest wall restriction. Acute decompensation likely due to aspiration pneumonitis, which has improved and the patient is now tolerating low-level PSV. Will repeat sputum culture given thick yellow sputum (no empiric antibiotics for now due to afebrile, WBC normal). Repeat TC trial today.
5. HTN - continue current regimen, blood pressure improved.

ICU care includes nutrition through enteral feeding, glycemic control, DVT prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin, stress ulcer prophylaxis with an H2 blocker, and ventilation-associated pneumonia (VAP) prevention with head-of-bed elevation and mouth care.

The patient's disposition is transfer to a rehabilitation or long-term care facility.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with chronic respiratory failure, tracheostomy, and recent neurological decline of unclear origin. She was admitted after a traumatic aspiration event and experienced hypoxemia and altered mental status. The patient also suffered from a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest due to hypoxemia/mucous plugging.

24-Hour Events:
- Neuro consult recommended sural nerve and gastrocnemius nerve biopsy to rule out critical illness myopathy.
- Home blood pressure medications were restarted.
- The patient did not tolerate a test dose given hypertension (SBP 200s) and tachycardia.
- Thick yellow sputum was suctioned out.

   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   #AFB: Patient with a positive AFB reported from lab on basis of
   suspicious gram stain lab took initiative to perform AFB
s.  Now on
   respiratory isolation.  Obtaining repeat AFB smears.  No known history
   of TB.  Would also consider [**Doctor First Name **] or nocardia.
   -          continue respiratory isolation, and await sensitivity and
   speciation on AFB.
   -          Chest X-ray, sputum, AFB as above.
   -          Will need PCR and will need to notifiy LTAC facility if
   positive result.
   .
   #Leukocytosis: New today.  Will work-up with CXR, Ua, Blood culture,
   sputum given slightly more lethargic appearance on exam.
   -          Concern for pneumonia in this patient with aspiration risk
   -          Defer treatment until source identified unless patient
   decompensates.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by
   aspiration and inability to clear secretions.  Per son pt was
   tolerating hours of [**Name (NI) **] at NH. Currently gas exchanging well on home
   vent settings. Has been tolerating PSV/CPAP.  This AM on [**9-22**], and
   adjusted to [**4-22**].
   - trial of trach mask [**4-16**]
 patient could not tolerate.  Otherwise at
   baseline on home CPAP settings.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures drawn, no growth on urine or blood,
   sputum with 1+ GPRs/GNR,  will continue to follow micro
   - repeat sputum given increased sputum production
   - D/c
d VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,
   fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA, growing what
   appears to be oral flora in sputum culture.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS today,
   # Altered Mental Status: Siginificantly improved since admission and at
   baseline although mildly more lethargic today.   Unclear if generalized
   toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated
   dilantin level), hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder
   (non-convulsive status) though this was not captured on EEG monitoring
   during last admission in [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only
   encephalopathic background).  At that time, appears to have had similar
   mental/functional status that she has now; however, per notes and her
   son, had been making improvements since that time.  During her last
   admission, had extensive neuro work up at that time which was largely
   unrevealing including LP, paraneoplastic labs which were negative,
   SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical illness
   myopathy.  Patient is currently interactive and follows commands.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, -> level subtherapeutic
   this AM, d/w neuro and will give 1x loading dose today and increase to
   150 TID.
   - Started Keppra
   - daily dilantin level
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   .
   # Vomiting/regurgitation: Had KUB on admission showing stool in the
   [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have led to worsening residuals, vomiting and aspiration.
   S/p aggressive bowel regimen with BM at this time.  Regurgitation also
   improved at this time.  Will start reglan standing and senna to assist
   with BM
s and avoid precipitating further aspiration.
   - held TF for increased residuals -> restart today as tolerated.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Acute renal failure: Resolved. Likely from pre-renal etiology in the
   setting of poor intake.  Patient initally appeared quite dry on exam.
   Chronically with foley so unlikely obstruction.
   - Trending Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.0 with
   hydration
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue tube feeds for
   now. Continue to monitor volume status.
   # Anemia: Still elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on some
   home meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, hydralazine, lopressor

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence. She was admitted for increased hypoxemia and altered mental status. The patient experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest in the setting of hypoxemia/mucous plugging.

The patient has shown improvement in hypoxemia and altered mental status. She has been placed in negative pressure isolation due to the presence of acid-fast bacilli (AFB) in her sputum culture. Repeat sputum samples have been sent for further testing.

The patient remains mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. The etiology of her chronic respiratory failure is unclear, with possibilities including neuromuscular weakness or chest wall restriction. Aspiration pneumonitis appears to be the most likely cause of her acute decompensation, as she has improved with low-grade pressure support ventilation (PSV) requirement, likely due to improved pneumonitis and pulmonary compliance.

The patient's altered mental status is uncertain, possibly post-PEA arrest. A head CT scan was normal, EEG showed no evidence of seizures, and no obvious infection was found. The neurology team believes her mental status is at her baseline.

The patient's seizure disorder is being managed with current anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs).

Acute renal failure is improving, hypertension is being treated, and the patient is receiving appropriate ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence. She was admitted for increased hypoxemia and altered mental status, both of which have improved. She experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest in the setting of hypoxemia/mucous plugging. Sputum culture with acid-fast bacilli (AFB) revealed the presence of AFB, indicating a possible Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with pressure support ventilation (PSV) and has shown improvement in respiratory failure due to improved pneumonitis and increased pulmonary compliance. Her altered mental status is being evaluated, with a head CT showing no abnormalities and an electroencephalogram (EEG) without any evidence of seizure activity. The neuro team believes her mental status is at her baseline. She also has acute renal failure, hypertension, and a seizure disorder. The patient is receiving appropriate ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's condition is critical, and further evaluation and treatment are required.

s in sputum.  Started cefepime yesterday
   for pneumonia.  Negative blood urine cultures to date.
   -          Concern for pneumonia in this patient with aspiration risk
   -          Defer treatment until source identified unless patient
   decompensates.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by
   aspiration and inability to clear secretions.  Per son pt was
   tolerating hours of [**Name (NI) **] at NH. Currently gas exchanging well on home
   vent settings. Has been tolerating PSV/CPAP.  This AM on [**9-22**], and
   adjusted to [**4-22**].
   - trial of trach mask [**4-16**]
 patient could not tolerate.  Otherwise at
   baseline on home CPAP settings.  Some increase in pressure support to
   14 today, likely [**1-19**] to pneumonia with component of volume overload as
   noted on CXR.
   - follow micro
   - repeat sputum given increased sputum production
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS today,
   # Altered Mental Status: Siginificantly improved since admission and at
   baseline although mildly more lethargic today.   Unclear if generalized
   toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated
   dilantin level), hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder
   (non-convulsive status) though this was not captured on EEG monitoring
   during last admission in [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only
   encephalopathic background).  At that time, appears to have had similar
   mental/functional status that she has now; however, per notes and her
   son, had been making improvements since that time.  During her last
   admission, had extensive neuro work up at that time which was largely
   unrevealing including LP, paraneoplastic labs which were negative,
   SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical illness
   myopathy.  Patient is currently interactive and follows commands.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, Phenytoin level mildly
   subtherapeutic.  D/W neurology regarding increased dose
   - Continue Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   - Sural nerve biopsy for neuropathy.
   .

s and avoid precipitating further aspiration.

   - Trending Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.0 with

   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue tube feeds for

   # Anemia: Prior baseline is 25, now at 30-34.  Suggests volume

   - IVF prn as above.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old individual with a history of seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence, and recent transfer for hypoxia and altered mental status. The patient has been admitted to the ICU and has been receiving various treatments and interventions.

Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia/Leukocytosis: The patient's sputum culture showed the presence of GNR bacteria. Cefepime was started for pneumonia treatment, but blood and urine cultures have been negative so far.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing worsening respiratory failure, likely due to aspiration from vomiting and inability to clear secretions. The patient is currently on home CPAP settings with increased pressure support to 14 cmH2O.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient has significantly improved since admission but remains lethargic. The cause of the altered mental status is unclear, possibly due to infection, hypoxia, drugs, or underlying seizure disorder.
4. Volume Status: The patient has an input-output imbalance, indicating potential fluid overload. Lasix has been given to promote diuresis.
5. Vomiting/Regurgitation: The patient has been experiencing regurgitation and vomiting, leading to worsening residuals and aspiration. Aggressive bowel regimen and medications like Reglan have been initiated to manage these symptoms.
6. Acute Renal Failure: The patient initially presented with acute renal failure, likely due to pre-renal etiology.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence. She was admitted for increased hypoxemia and altered mental status, both of which have improved. The patient suffered a PEA arrest in the setting of hypoxemia/mucous plugging on day PTA. She has been diagnosed with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) infection in her sputum and has been placed in a negative pressure room. The patient's respiratory failure persists, and she remains on mechanical ventilation due to hypertension and visible distress. She also has increased secretions and is back on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis). 

The etiology of the patient's chronic respiratory failure is unclear, with possible causes including neuromuscular weakness (NM) or chest wall restriction. A sural nerve biopsy has been planned to help differentiate between post-polio, critical care myopathy, or other etiologies. The patient's PSV (pressure support ventilation) requirement has decreased, likely due to improved pneumonitis and increased pulmonary compliance. 

The patient's altered mental status may be post-PEA arrest, but her head CT is normal, EEG shows no evidence of seizures, and no obvious infection is present. The neuro team believes that her mental status is at her baseline. The patient's seizure disorder requires further evaluation by neurology, and she will continue on her current anti-ep

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence. She was admitted for increased hypoxemia and altered mental status, both of which have improved. She suffered a PEA arrest due to hypoxemia/mucous plugging. The patient has an active infection with positive AFB in her sputum, indicating a possible tuberculosis infection. She also has increased GNR in her sputum and is being treated with cefipime. The patient remains on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure, which is likely caused by either neuromuscular weakness or chest wall restriction. The etiology of her chronic respiratory failure is unclear. An altered mental status persists, possibly post-PEA arrest, and further evaluation by the neurology team is needed. The patient's seizure disorder requires ongoing management. She has acute renal failure that is improving, and her hypertension is being managed. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen if there are complications from mechanical ventilation or if her underlying neuromuscular weakness or chest wall restriction worsens.
2. Tuberculosis Infection: The positive AFB in the sputum indicates an active tuberculosis infection. If left untreated or inadequately treated, this could lead to disease progression and complications.
3. Sepsis: The presence of increased GNR in the sputum suggests a bacterial infection. If the infection spreads to the

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old F with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Pseudomonal pneumonia: Moderate growth of pseudomonas on sputum
   cuilture from [**4-16**], sensitive to cefepime.  Blood cultures with NGTD,
   and urine cultures negative.   Moderate AFB on concentrated smear, non
   TB.  We discontinued respiratory isolation.
   -continue cefepime for a seven day course
   # Respiratory Failure: Underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Possibly related to pneumonia.  Currently on CPAP at 14/5,
   which is increased from her baseline given her PNA and volume overload.
   -Continue to wean pressure support as tolerated to home settings.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   # Altered Mental Status: Siginificantly improved since admission and at
   baseline although mildly more lethargic today.   Unclear if generalized
   toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated
   dilantin level), hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder
   (non-convulsive status) though this was not captured on EEG monitoring
   during last admission in [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only
   encephalopathic background).  At that time, appears to have had similar
   mental/functional status that she has now; however, per notes and her
   son, had been making improvements since that time.  During her last
   admission, had extensive neuro work up at that time which was largely
   unrevealing including LP, paraneoplastic labs which were negative,
   SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical illness myopathy.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, Phenytoin level mildly
   subtherapeutic.  D/W neurology regarding increased dose
   - Continue Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   - Sural nerve biopsy for neuropathy.
   #Volume Status: Even over the last 24 hours with lasix
   -continue lasix bolus of 40mg IV to keep I/O even
   # Vomiting/regurgitation: Had KUB on admission showing stool in the
   [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have led to worsening residuals, vomiting and aspiration.
   S/p aggressive bowel regimen with BM at this time.  Regurgitation also
   improved at this time.  Will start reglan standing and senna to assist
   with BM
s and avoid precipitating further aspiration.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be 27-28.  stable
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on some
   home meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, hydralazine, lopressor
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Tube feeds
   Glycemic Control: Not needed

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and transfer for hypoxia and altered mental status. Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pseudomonal pneumonia: The patient has moderate growth of pseudomonas on sputum culture, which is sensitive to cefepime. It is important to continue the appropriate antibiotic therapy to prevent the spread of the infection and further complications.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure of unclear etiology needs to be managed carefully. She is currently on CPAP at 14/5, which has been increased from her baseline due to pneumonia and volume overload. Weaning off pressure support as tolerated and implementing aggressive pulmonary toilet is necessary to improve her respiratory function.

3. Altered mental status: The patient's significantly improved mental status since admission indicates a positive response to treatment. However, her lethargy today may suggest a mild worsening. It is important to continue monitoring her mental status and addressing any potential underlying causes such as generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs, hypoxia, or underlying seizure disorder.

4. Myopathy: The patient has been diagnosed with critical illness myopathy, likely related to her prolonged mechanical ventilation. A sural nerve biopsy has

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence. She was admitted for increased hypoxemia and altered mental status. The patient suffered a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest in the setting of hypoxemia/mucous plugging. She has been diagnosed with pseudomonas pneumonia and is currently being treated with cefipime. Her white blood cell count has improved, but she still has secretions. The respiratory failure etiology is unclear, whether it is due to neuromuscular disease or chest wall restriction. A plan for a sural nerve biopsy has been made to differentiate between post-polio syndrome, critical care myopathy, or other etiologies. The patient's positive sputum culture for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) indicates possible tuberculosis (TB), and a PCR test has been sent to rule out Mycobacterium tuberculosis. No empirical treatment for TB has been started yet. The patient's altered mental status may be due to post-PEA arrest, but a head CT was normal, EEG showed no seizure activity, and no obvious infection was found. The neurology team believes her mental status is at her baseline. The patient's acute renal failure is improving, and she will be given lasix to keep her fluid balance closer to even. Hypertension will be managed with the current regimen. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition through total parenteral nutrition (TPN), glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers. The patient's code status is full code, and she will remain in the ICU.

She was admitted for increased hypoxemia and altered mental status. The patient suffered from a PEA arrest in the setting of hypoxemia/mucous plugging. Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, transferred for hypoxia, and altered mental status. She has been diagnosed with pseudomonal pneumonia, for which she is receiving cefepime. Her altered mental status has improved since admission but remains mildly lethargic. The patient also has anemia, hypertension (mostly during breathing trials), and vomiting/regurgitation issues. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient has pseudomonal pneumonia, which requires treatment with antibiotics. There is also a mention of potential infection contributing to her altered mental status.
2. Status Epilepticus: The patient was found to be in status epilepticus, and she is at risk of recurrent episodes.
3. Anoxia Brain Injury: The patient had a cardiac arrest in the past, which could have led to anoxia brain injury contributing to her altered mental status.
4. Hypotension: The patient experienced hypotension requiring fluid boluses and a switch from CPAP to AC.
5. Aspiration: The patient has regurgitation and vomiting issues, which can lead to aspiration, especially during breathing trials.
6. Chronic Ventilator Dependence: The patient has a history of chronic ventilator dependence, indicating a potential long-term respiratory issue.
7. Sural Nerve Biopsy: The patient is planned for a sural nerve biopsy once stable, suggesting a possible underlying neurop

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, hypoxia, and altered mental status. She was transferred to the ICU for further management. The patient has been experiencing subclinical status epilepticus, which was confirmed through EEG monitoring. She was given lorazepam and dilantin as per neurologist recommendations. Due to the use of ativan, her MAPs and respiratory rate dropped, requiring fluid boluses and a switch from CPAP to AC. Brain MRI was held off until she stabilized. A family meeting was held, and they decided to postpone the sural nerve biopsy due to her acute decompensation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pseudomonal pneumonia: The patient has moderate growth of pseudomonas on sputum culture, indicating a possible infection. It is essential to continue cefepime for a seven-day course to treat this infection.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has been deteriorating over the last three days, and she was found to be in non-convulsive status epilepticus. The cause could be anoxic brain injury post-cardiac arrest, infection, or underlying seizure disorder. Further investigations are needed to determine the exact cause.
3. Volume Status: The patient has a low urine output of 600 cc in the last 24 hours while experiencing hypotension. This indicates a potential volume depletion. It is

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of post-polio syndrome, chronic respiratory failure, and being ventilator-dependent. She was admitted with hypoxemia, altered mental status, and weakness, suspected to have critical illness neuropathy and possible pneumonia (PNA). Over the last two days, her mental status has worsened, and she experienced subclinical status epilepticus. The patient requires continuous EEG monitoring, and she is unresponsive. Her respiratory failure is due to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and critical illness neuropathy. She is currently on cefepime for PNA and requires IV fluids for hypotension. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia (PNA): The patient is at risk for developing pneumonia due to being ventilator-dependent and having a weakened immune system.
2. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): Given her prolonged mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Critical Illness Myopathy/Neuropathy: The patient's weakness and altered mental status may be indicative of critical illness myopathy or neuropathy, which can be caused by prolonged immobilization, sedation, and the use of certain medications.
4. Status Epilepticus: The patient's recent episode of subclinical status epilepticus indicates a potential for recurrent seizures or further neurological complications.
5. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure requires close monitoring

- Lab results show elevated white blood cell count, normal hemoglobin, slightly low platelet count, normal creatinine, and slightly elevated glucose levels.

   76 year old F with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Pseudomonal pneumonia: Moderate growth of pseudomonas on sputum
   cuilture from [**4-16**], sensitive to cefepime.  Blood cultures with NGTD,
   and urine cultures negative.   Moderate AFB on concentrated smear, non
   TB.  Have discontinued respiratory isolation.
   - continue cefepime for a seven day course through [**2115-4-24**] (adjust
   dose for renal function)
   - continue with AC for now given tenuous hemodynamic status,  RSBI 138
   this am

   .
    # Altered Mental Status: more lethargic last 3 days, found to be in
   status epilepticus, ddx anoxi brain injury s/p cardiac arrest ,
   infection.   Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from
   infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level), hypoxia, or from
   underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status) though this was not
   captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro
   ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At that time, appears to
   have had similar mental/functional status that she has now; however,
   per notes and her son, had been making improvements since that time.
   During her last admission, had extensive neuro work up at that time
   which was largely unrevealing including LP, paraneoplastic labs which
   were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical
   illness myopathy.
   - subclinical status epilepticus- keppra, phenytoin, follow daily
   phenytoin levels
   - Neuro recs, MRI brain to be coordinated with neuro, currently on 24
   hour EEG monitoring
   - Continue Keppra
   - continuous EEG monitoring
   - Sural nerve biopsy for neuropathy once stable - family not willing to
   consent as patient in satus
   .

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, hypoxia, and altered mental status. She was transferred to the ICU for further management. The patient has been experiencing episodes of status epilepticus, and her mental status has been deteriorating over the last three days. She has moderate growth of pseudomonas on sputum culture, which is sensitive to cefepime. Blood cultures with NGTD and urine cultures are negative. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with an RSBI of 138. She has large bilateral pleural effusions and bilateral atelectases on chest X-ray. The patient's renal function is impaired, as indicated by elevated creatinine levels. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low calcium level. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and she has a low platelet count. She has moderate AFB on concentrated smear, which is non-TB. The patient's medications include cefepime, propofol, phenytoin, and levetiracetam.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pseudomonal pneumonia: The patient has moderate growth of pseudomonas on sputum culture, which is sensitive to cefepime. She should continue to receive cefepime for a seven-day course through [**2115-4-24**]. Monitoring for signs of improvement or worsening

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, hypoxia, and altered mental status. She was transferred to the ICU for further evaluation and management. The patient has been experiencing multiple medical complications including pseudomonal pneumonia, altered mental status, vomiting/regurgitation, anemia, and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pseudomonal pneumonia: The patient has moderate growth of pseudomonas on sputum culture, which is sensitive to cefepime. She should continue receiving cefepime for a seven-day course through [**2115-4-23**] (adjust dose for renal function). Monitoring for improvement in respiratory symptoms and daily cultures should be done.

2. Altered mental status: The patient has been more lethargic over the last three days and was found to be in status epilepticus. The differential diagnosis includes anoxic brain injury after cardiac arrest, infection, or underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status). It is unclear if generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level), hypoxia, or from the underlying seizure disorder. The patient is currently sedated with propofol, and EEG monitoring is being continued. The plan includes subclinical status epilepticus management with keppra, phenytoin, and follow-up daily phenytoin levels. An MRI brain should be coordinated

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and altered mental status. She was transferred for hypoxia and has been diagnosed with pseudomonal pneumonia, which is sensitive to cefepime. The patient is also showing signs of anemia, hypertension, and possible toxic metabolic encephalopathy due to infection, drugs, hypoxia, or underlying seizure disorder. She has been experiencing vomiting/regurgitation and has had an aggressive bowel regimen. The patient's current medications include propofol, cefepime, and AC (possibly acetaminophen or another medication). Her vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 122/56 mmHg, heart rate of 74 bpm, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient is sedated and unresponsive.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient has pseudomonal pneumonia, which needs to be treated with appropriate antibiotics. There is a risk of worsening infection or development of new infections due to her immunocompromised state.
2. Seizure disorder: The patient has a history of seizures, and she is currently experiencing nonconvulsive status epilepticus. Proper management of her seizure disorder is essential to prevent further seizures and potential complications.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is relatively low, indicating potential hypotension. Close monitoring and

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old individual with post-polio syndrome, chronic respiratory failure, and ventilator dependence. They have been experiencing status epilepticus and PSA PNA. The patient's medical history, social history, family history, and review of systems are unchanged from admission except for the noted events above.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.8°C (98.2°F), a heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 120/67 to 141/84 mmHg, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation level of 99%. The patient's weight is currently 63.8 kg, with a height of 66 inches.

The patient has received several medications, including phenytoin, propofol, cefepime, folate, sinemet, iron, Synthroid, persantine, chlorhexidine, calcium carbonate, vitamin D, keppra, dilantin, senna, and aspirin.

The patient's flow sheet data shows fluid balance, hemodynamic monitoring, and respiratory support. The respiratory support includes a ventilator mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, set tidal volume (Vt) of 400 mL, set respiratory rate (RR) of 12 breaths per minute, peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 20 cmH2O, plateau pressure of 18 cmH2O,

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old F with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Pseudomonal pneumonia: Moderate growth of pseudomonas on sputum
   cuilture from [**2037-4-14**], sensitive to cefepime.  Blood cultures with
   NGTD, and urine cultures negative.   Moderate AFB on concentrated
   smear, non TB.  Have discontinued respiratory isolation.
   - continue cefepime for a seven day course through [**2115-4-23**] (adjust
   dose for renal function)
   .
    # Altered Mental Status: Ffound to be in sub-clinical status
   epilepticus- unclear etiology.  Differential includes anoxic brain
   injury as patient had a PEA prior to admission, toxic/metabolic
   encephalopathy from infection vs drugs (patient had  mildly elevated
   dilantin level), or underlying seizure disorder..  MRI negative for
   mass or infectious focus.   She had a prior admission with similar
   altered mental status, however, EEG was negative at that time.  She had
   an extensive neuro work up at that time which was largely unrevealing
   including LP, paraneoplastic labs which were negative, SPEP/UPEP,
   MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical illness myopathy.
   - continue midazolam, keppra, phenytoin, follow daily phenytoin levels
   - follow up final read of MRI
   - Follow up EEG read
   - Neuro recs
   - Sural nerve biopsy for neuropathy once stable - family not willing to
   consent as patient in satus
   .
    #Volume Status:
   - bolus for UOP<30cc/hr/ MAP <65
   - hold BP meds
   .
   # Vomiting/regurgitation: Had KUB on admission showing stool in the
   [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have led to worsening residuals, vomiting and aspiration.
   S/p aggressive bowel regimen with BM at this time.  Regurgitation also
   improved at this time.  Will start senna and colace to assist with BM
   and avoid precipitating further aspiration.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   .
    # Anemia: Baseline appears to be 27-28.  stable
   .
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on some
   home meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, hydralazine, lopressor all being HELD
   given hypotension with dilantin/propofol.  Would restart labetalol
   first w/ hydralazine next for afterload reduction.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Tube feeds

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of chronic ventilator dependence, seizure disorder, and recent hospital-acquired pneumonia. She was transferred for hypoxia and altered mental status. The patient's current condition includes subclinical status epilepticus, which is still not fully understood. Imaging and lab tests have not revealed any clear seizure foci, infection, stroke, or other abnormalities.

The patient has moderate pan-sensitive pseudomonas on sputum culture, but blood and urine cultures are negative. She also has moderate acid-fast bacilli on concentrated smear, which is non-TB. Respiratory isolation has been discontinued.

The patient's altered mental status could be due to various factors such as anoxic brain injury, toxic/metabolic encephalopathy from infection or drugs, or underlying seizure disorder. An MRI of the brain was negative for mass or infectious focus.

The patient is being treated with midazolam, keppra, and phenytoin for the status epilepticus. Phenytoin levels will be followed daily, and a final read of the MRI will be done. An EEG read and neuro recommendations are also pending.

The patient's volume status is being closely monitored, and she is receiving aggressive bowel regimen to improve vomiting and regurgitation. Her baseline anemia appears to be stable at 27-28%. Hypertension is mostly a problem during breathing trials, and some home medications have been restarted with improvement

Summary:
The patient is a 66-inch, 63.8 kg male who presented with status epilepticus and respiratory failure. The patient has been admitted to the ICU and received a PICC line on 04/21/2115 at 05:45 PM. The patient underwent magnetic resonance imaging, which revealed microvascular ischemic changes. The patient was initially treated with propofol but experienced hypotension and continued seizure activity, leading to the conversion to a midazolam drip at 1 mg/hr. The patient's allergies include no known drug allergies. The patient has been receiving various medications, including cefepime, levetiracetam (Keppra), and midazolam. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 141/71 to 100/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, set tidal volume of 400 mL, set respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and plateau pressure of 19 cmH2O. The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 16.6 K/uL, hemoglobin of 27.5 g
